description: From Medieval Latin connotō (“signify beyond literal meaning”), from com- (“together”), + notō (“mark”).

verbs.description: connote (third-person singular simple present connotes, present participle connoting, simple past and past participle connoted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To signify beyond its literal or principal meaning.
examples: Racism often connotes an underlying fear or ignorance.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To possess an inseparable related condition; to imply as a logical consequence.
(intransitive) To express without overt reference; to imply.
(intransitive) To require as a logical predicate to consequence.
